A guage of 5 feet 6 inches has been adopted by the Company ;
this has been done with reference to connection with other Western
roads. The adoption of this guage by the Pacific or St. Louis Road,
and now by ours, will establish this as the uniform guage West of
the Mississippi River.
The grading of the whole road is very light. Over a large portion, the embankments are only rail igh to ensure
perfect drainage. From Berwick's Bay to Washington, with the
exception of about four miles, the whole line is high and dry above
any danger of overflow. A portion of the lower division is subject
to the overflow of crevasses. It has never been calculated to build
the road above high water mark—there would be many objections
to it. By it the cost of the road would be vastly increased, whilst
it would operate greatly to the injury of all the lands between the
road and the river. In the time of a crevasse instead of the water
being allowed to run back and spread over the swamps and low
ground, in the rear of the river, it would be dammed up by the embankments of the road, thereby causing the whole of the land next
the river to be overflowed. This plan would meet wilh violent opposition from all the planters on -the river. Instead of this, it is proposed to place as little obstruction as possible in the way of crevasse
water, by building our embankments sufficiently far from the river,
as to allow the force of the current to be spent before reaching
them, and building only so high as to ensure drainage, we sustain
no injury, except from a temporary delay in the operation of the
Efficient means should also be taken to guard against crevasses,
by having all exposed points properly secured.
It is to be considered too, that the construction itself of the road,
will make the danger of crevasses less than they are now, as it will
be the means of speedy transportation of workmen and materials to
any point that may be threatened. Immediately where a crevasse
occurs, the water runs through it with great velocity, but it soon
spreads over a large extent of ground, losing its velocity as it recedes from the river, until at a distance of a half mile it is not sufficient to injure our embankments, protected as they will be by a
thick matting of grass and weeds.
